div.p: You wouldn’t buy a car without a dashboard and you wouldn’t run a service without a
good understanding of how well it’s being used by your customers, by businesses and
citizens. I think the data is absolutely fundamental to being able to take good decisions about
the management of that service. In the private sector, companies like Amazon
and Twitter, they will go bust if they don’t focus on the user needs for their customers.
Government often is the only person providing a particular service to citizens and businesses,
but it’s no less important that we are responsive to the needs of our users.
Statistics don’t have a reputation for far-side reading, it it’s valuable whether the data
is numbers or whether it’s words to make sure that there is a focused presentation
to cut to the crux of what people need to know in order to make the decisions about
the services that they’re responsible for. Too often data is given to people in enormous
quantity and people find it difficult to filter out what is essential and what is merely interesting.
By making sure that the visual presentation of these products are sharp, we hope to save
time and to make sure that people focus on the main thing.
We think a consistent set of management information for all departments is really, really important
to get a set of benchmarks for what good looks like across government services, but also
to make sure that these services are focused on the needs and the concerns of their users.
So information relating to user satisfaction, the cost per transaction for those services,
the digitalisation of those services, how digital they are, and the success rate is
all really generically useful information, regardless of what kind of service it is.
